net.java.jddac.common.type
Class ArgArray

java.lang.Object
  net.java.jddac.common.type.ArgArray
Direct Known Subclasses:
Measurement, Record
public class ArgArray
extends java.lang.Object

The ArgArray class is the fundamental building block in JDDAC for passing information between objects. It is designed to be a simple container class compatible with both J2ME and J2SE. In one sense it can be viewed as simply a Hashtable>/code> with nameed objects for contents. However, a number of get/set members are provided to simplify access to the internals of the ArgArray contents. Some of the features of the ArgArray class are:

  • Typesafe get methods.
  • Fundamental type put methods (int, long, etc).
  • Ability to specify default values if a get would otherwise return null.
  • Ability to do basic units conversion on get methods.
  • Ability to lock contents from being changed accidently.
  • Ability to determine if one ArgArray is a subset of another ArgArray.
  • Ability to merge one ArgArray into another.
  • Ability to provide a 'backing store' of default ArgArray contents.
  • Ability to convert easily to String for debugging.
To successfully store and retrieve objects from an ArgArray, the objects used as keys must implement the hashCode method and the equals method.

          An interface to allow conversion of complex types to and from an ArgArray.

          The UnitsConverter interface provides a mechanism to attach advanced unit conversion capabilities to certain get methods.

ArgArray

public ArgArray(java.lang.Object[][] strings)
Create an ArgArray from an array of key/value pairs. Example code: ArgArray args=createFromKeyValuePairs(new String[][]{"1","abc"}, {"2","efg"}});

Parameters:
strings - The array containing the key/value pairs.
Method Detail

setUnitsConverter

public void setUnitsConverter(ArgArray.UnitsConverter converter)
Specify a default units conversion engine to assist with extracting values from ArgArrays. The converter must implement the ArgArray.UnitsConverter interface. A single global converter is used for all ArgArray instances so setting this value will globally affect conversions. By default a basic converter is provided internally to the ArgArray implementation.

Parameters:
converter - - the converter.

cloneContentsTo

public void cloneContentsTo(ArgArray dest)
Clone the contents of the dest argument into the existing ArgArray. The existing contents are not removed before the clone is performed so this essentially acts as an add and replace operation. Note that the first level object references are copied so this is not a deep clone operation. To do a deep clone you can use the method on an empty ArgArray.

Parameters:
dest - - the ArgArray to fill with new contents.

getHashtable

public java.util.Hashtable getHashtable()
Return a Hashtable instance representing the internal contents. This value is useful for iterating over the contents. Note that the Hashtable returned is not the one used internally by the ArgArray internals.

Returns:
- the internal contents as a Hashtable

getDefault

public ArgArray getDefault()
Obtain a reference to the internal default ArgArray settings.

Returns:
- the internal default ArgArray.

setDefault

public void setDefault(ArgArray def)
Set the default 'backing store' for the ArgArray. Requests for values not found by user set operations are returned from the default set. null is returned if the request cannot be satisfied by either mechanism. Note that since the default settings is itself an ArgArray the retrieval of the value is can be recursive. That is, the default ArgArray can itself have it's own default ArgArray.

Parameters:
def - - the ArgArray to use for the default settings.

clear

public void clear()
Clears this ArgArray so it contains no values or defaults.

lock

public void lock()
Prevent updates to the contents. Attempts to modify a locked ArgArray will result in an ArrayStoreException being thrown.

unlock

public void unlock()
Allow updates to the contents if previously locked.

locked

public boolean locked()
Returns the current lock state of the ArgArray.

Returns:
- the current lock state.

isSubsetOf

public boolean isSubsetOf(ArgArray arg0)
Compare the argument array to self and return true if the argument has zero elements that are not already in the ArgArray. Stated another way, this method returns true if arg0 is a subset of this.

Parameters:
arg0 - - the ArgArray to compare to self.
Returns:
- true if they argument is a subset.

public java.lang.Object put(java.lang.Object key,

getInt

public int getInt(java.lang.String key,
                  int defaultValue,
                  java.lang.String units)
Extract an int value with optional application of internal unit scaling. For platforms where the internal representation of a floating point number is not convenient (J2ME/CLDC1.0) our where the basic internal usage is something like milliseconds, the caller can specified the desired integer internal units. For example, if an internal delay is stored in milliseconds to be compatible with many java delay/wait/timeout parameters, one can specify "ms" as the unit. This will cause values such as 1.123 to return as 1123 (ms). Or, 4578us would return as 4578 (ms). If a unit is not specified (either null or empty) then the internal units are presumed to be the fundamental SI unit without any scaling.

Parameters:
key - - the name of the value to extract
defaultValue - - the value to use if an error occurs.
units - - The desired internal units, can be null.
Returns:
- An integer scaled to the specified internal units.

getLong

public long getLong(java.lang.String key,
                    long defaultValue,
                    java.lang.String toUnits)
Extract a long value with optional application of internal unit scaling. For platforms where the internal representation of a floating point number is not convenient (J2ME/CLDC1.0) our where the basic internal usage is something like milliseconds, the caller can specified the desired integer internal units. For example, if an internal delay is stored in milliseconds to be compatible with many java delay/wait/timeout parameters, one can specify "ms" as the unit. This will cause values such as 1.123 to return as 1123 (ms). Or, 4578us would return as 4578 (ms). If a unit is not specified (either null or empty) then the internal units are presumed to be the fundamental SI unit without any scaling.

Parameters:
key - - the name of the value to extract
defaultValue - - the value to use if an error occurs.
toUnits - - The desired internal units, can be null.
Returns:
- A long scaled to the specified internal units.

add

public void add(ArgArray newStuff)
Add the top-level contents of the specified ArgArray. Existing entries with the same key name are replaced with object references from the source ArgArray.

Parameters:
newStuff - - the ArgArray contents to add.

deepAdd

public void deepAdd(ArgArray newStuff,
                    int vectorMode)
Performs a deep add of the contents of the specified ArgArray. Existing ArgArrays are not replaced but are instead 'augmented' with values from newStuff. Scalar values are replaced. When adding a Vector at places where a Vector already exists, the behaviour is controlled by the vectorMode argument to allow one of error, replace, insert, or append.

Parameters:
newStuff - - the ArgArray contents to add.
vectorMode - - One of MODE_REPLACE, VECTOR_MODE_INSERT, VECTOR_MODE_APPEND, VECTOR_MODE_ERROR to control how vectors are added to existing vectors.

deepAdd

public void deepAdd(ArgArray newStuff)
Performs a deep add of the contents of the specified ArgArray. This is equivalent to calling deepAdd(newStuff,MODE_REPLACE).

Parameters:
newStuff -

deepCloneVector

public static java.util.Vector deepCloneVector(java.util.Vector v)
Create a new Vector copy where all of the container objects (ArgArray and Vector) in the result are newly created. Contents which represent scalar types (as opposed to code>ArgArray and Vector) are copied by refernce so new objects are not created.

Parameters:
v -
Returns:
